user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer:
```c
static bool
has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_BODY_RECEIVING == c->state);
  if (! c->rq.have_chunked_upload)
    return 0 != c->read_buffer_offset;

  /* Chunked upload */
  mhd_assert (0 != c->rq.remaining_upload_size); /* Must not be possible in MHD_CONNECTION_BODY_RECEIVING state */
  if (c->rq.current_chunk_offset == c->rq.current_chunk_size)
  {
    /* 0 == c->rq.current_chunk_size: Waiting the chunk size (chunk header).
       0 != c->rq.current_chunk_size: Waiting for chunk-closing CRLF. */
    return false;
  }
  return 0 != c->read_buffer_offset; /* Chunk payload data in the read buffer */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided function and related macro definition for any use of the Standard Library function memcmp or any string-comparison using memcmp on null-terminated strings. No call to memcmp appears in the function or the provided macro. The function only uses integer/boolean tests (comparisons against 0) and accesses members of the connection structure (e.g. have_chunked_upload, read_buffer_offset, current_chunk_offset, current_chunk_size, remaining_upload_size). The mhd_assert macro is defined as a no-op ((void)0). There are no string operations or includes shown that would indicate memcmp is being used indirectly. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
